review: This little fob is AWESOME.  We travel quite a bit and only take our ipad with Netflix.  Now kids can watch their Netflix movies & shows on the TV instead of huddling around a little screen, and we can watch documentaries, series, etc while we're away from home.  You have to make sure TV has proper HDMI input.  Sometimes can be a little finicky to setup but once you figure it out youre good. Sometimes would disconnect after non-use for a day or two, but just unplugged everything to reset and it reconnected no problem.

review: If you're looking for one more way to 'cut the cable' or 'dish', this is one sweet little tool. Basically anything you can upload to your computer screen can be 'broadcast' to the Chromecast dongle. Just plug it into the HDMI input on your flat screen TV or your amp and load the software at the webpage. The rest is even easier. Click on the icon when you have loaded the page and 'voile' it's projected to your TV. Works great with YouTube and hundreds of other video streaming websites many of which are free online. You have the option of using a USB cable or the 'wall wart' power supply. I chose the USB since it was available on my TV. Even while you're making your decision on what to watch the Chromecast has some incredible backgrounds/screensavers to entertain. I spent nearly an hour just appreciating the 'breath-taking' images shot by professional and amateur photographer. With the cost of cable and dish services escalating out of control, I decided to spend a few dollars once or twice a year on programming I prefer rather than a hundred dollars every month for stations I never watch. So far I have invested in ROKU, Chromecast, BasicTalk and FIOS internet. I have disconnected dish services and land-line phone and am still saving 50 percent of what I was spending. I highly recommend this approach to selective 'intelligent' viewing.
